prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 14 Serpens targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band-7 observations at 0.12'' resolution of 14 transition disks in Serpens. They include the CO (3-2) line and a 7.5 GHz bandwith for continnum observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request the highest spatial resolution available for Cycle-2 observations in band-7 (0.12'') because our targets are expected to have small disks (r < 30-50 AU)and measuring their sizes is one of the main science objectives.
We use a very standard spectral setup that includes the CO (3-2) line with a 0.8 km/s resolution and 7.5 GHz bandwith for continuum observations.
We request a continuum rms sensitivity of 0.15 mJy, equivalent to 3-sigma limit of 0.3 M_jup for the detectable disk masses a the distance of Serpens (see eq.1 in the scientific justification).
2MASS J044427+2512, the M7.25 BD in Taurus (140 pc) mentioned in the scientific justification is 5.2 mJy at 1.3 mm. Circumstellar disks are typically a factor of 2 brighter at 850 microns than at 1.3 mm (Andrews et al. 2005;2007). 2MASS J044427+2512 would then expected to be 1.2 mJy in band-7 if placed at distance of Serpens (415 pc) and would be detectable with a S/N of ~8.
The overheads are large simply because ALMA is extremelly sensitive and only a couple of minutes of exposure time per source are needed to reach our science objectives.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 13 Perseus targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band-7 observations at 0.12'' resolution of 13 transition disks in Perseus. They include the CO(3-2) line and a 7.5 GHz bandwith for continnum observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request the highest spatial resolution available for Cycle-2 observations in band-7 (0.12'') because our targets are expected to have small disks (r < 30-50 AU)and measuring their sizes is one of the main science objectives.
We use a very standard spectral setup that includes the CO (3-2) line with a 0.8 km/s resolution and 7.5 GHz bandwith for continuum observations.
We request a continuum rms sensitivity of 0.15 mJy, equivalent to 3-sigma limit of 0.1 M_jup for the detectable disk masses at the distance of Perseus (see eq. 1 in the scientific justification).
2MASS J044427+2512, the M7.25 BD in Taurus (140 pc) mentioned in the scientific justification is 5.2 mJy at 1.3 mm. Circumstellar disks are typically a factor of 2 brighter at 850 microns than at 1.3 mm (Andrews et al. 2005;2007). 2MASS J044427+2512 would then expected to be 3.3 mJy in band-7 if placed at distance of Perseus (250 pc) and would be detectable with a S/N of ~20.
The overheads are large simply because ALMA is extremelly sensitive and only a couple of minutes of exposure time per source are needed to reach our science objectives.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: 4 Ophiuchus targets
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Band-7 observations at 0.12'' resolution of 4 transition disks in Ophiuchus. The observations include the CO (3-2) line and a 7.5 GHz bandwith for continnum observations.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We request the highest spatial resolution available for Cycle-2 observations in band-7 (0.12'') because our targets are expected to have small disks (r < 30-50 AU)and measuring their sizes is one of the main science objectives.
We use a very standard spectral setup that includes the CO (3-2) line with a 0.8 km/s resolution and 7.5 GHz bandwith for continuum observations.
To make a more ifficent use of ALMA, we request the same continuum rms sensitivity of 0.15 mJy as in the other 2 science goals with targets that are much farther away.
The Ophiuchus objects are very likley to be well resolved and will provide an opportunity to study their surface density profile in detail.
The overheads are large simply because ALMA is extremelly sensitive and only a couple of minutes of exposure time per source are needed to reach our science objectives.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The gaps and inner holes of transition disks are considered to be the most likely sites of ongoing giant planet formation. Transition disks are found around stars with a wide range of spectral types (i.e., stellar masses) from Herbig Ae/Be to M-type stars. Transition disk SEDs are also seen around Brown Dwarfs (BDs) but almost nothing is know about the properties of such BD transition objects. The transition disk phenomenon in VLMSs and BDs is very intriguing and suggests they might also be able to form planets massive enough to open wide holes in their disks. Here we propose an ALMA Band-7 survey at 0.12'' resolution to estimate the sizes and masses of 31 recently identified transition disks around Very Low Mass Stars (VLMSs) and BDs in the Serpens, Perseus, and Ophiuchus molecular clouds. The masses and sizes of circumstellar disks are arguably their most fundamental properties and will allow us to assess their planet formation potential, that is the masses and (initial) semi-major axes of the planets that can be formed around hosts at the stellar/substellar boundary.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
